title: Three-Dimensional Imaging of the Symbiotic Interface Using Volume Electron Microscopy
content: Volume electron microscopy is a powerful to monitor the interaction that cannot be replicated in vitro, especially the ones cannot be replicated in cell cultures. Especially visualization of symbiotic interface can benefit from volume electron microscopy for understanding the interaction. Previously, the endosymbiosis between hard ticks and alphaproteobacterial endosymbionts came to light using two-dimensional microscopy [1]. The primary Lyme disease vector tick, Ixodes ricinus, carries an intracellular bacterial endosymbiont, Midichloria mitochondrii, in the ovaries [2]. The endosymbiont is maternally transmitted, the dynamics were not known until the three-dimensional (3D) imaging [3].
